informal_statement:
Suppose that $a$ and $b$ are nonzero real numbers, and that the [[equation]] $x^2 + ax + b = 0$ has solutions $a$ and $b$. Then the pair $(a,b)$ is

$\mathrm{(A)}\ (-2,1)
\qquad\mathrm{(B)}\ (-1,2)
\qquad\mathrm{(C)}\ (1,-2)
\qquad\mathrm{(D)}\ (2,-1)
\qquad\mathrm{(E)}\ (4,4)$ Show that it is \mathrm{(C)}\ (1,-2).
informal_proof: Since $(x-a)(x-b) = x^2 - (a+b)x + ab = x^2 + ax + b = 0$, it follows by comparing [[coefficient]]s that $-a - b = a$ and that $ab = b$. Since $b$ is nonzero, $a = 1$, and $-1 - b = 1 \Longrightarrow b = -2$. Thus $(a,b) = \mathrm{(C)}\ (1,-2)$.
formal_statement:
theorem amc12b_2002_p6:
  fixes a b :: real
  assumes "a \<noteq> 0 \<and> b \<noteq> 0"
      and "\<forall> x. x^2 + a * x + b = (x - a) * (x - b)"
    shows " a = 1 \<and> b = -2"
formal_code:
(*
  Authors: Wenda Li
*)
theory amc12b_2002_p6 
  imports Complex_Main
begin

theorem amc12b_2002_p6:
  fixes a b :: real
  assumes "a \<noteq> 0 \<and> b \<noteq> 0"
      and "\<forall> x. x^2 + a * x + b = (x - a) * (x - b)"
    shows " a = 1 \<and> b = -2"
  using assms 
  by (metis (no_types, opaque_lifting) Groups.mult_ac(2) Rings.ring_distribs(2) add.inverse_inverse 
      add_uminus_conv_diff diff_0 diff_numeral_special(10) mult.left_neutral 
      mult_cancel_left power2_eq_square right_minus_eq)
end
